Hello,

> If you really don't want your tests to be isolated, then I agree this
is 
> a waste of resources, but I have two questions:

> 1. Do you really want your tests /not/ to be isolated?

^^^^^^^^^^

Yes, I want the test cases to be isolated, that is test 2 fails and test
5 can still pass... that's why I need to use the 3rd party tool like
JUnit, otherwise, I would write my own test cases.

But I don't see by create each instance of the test class can ensure
isolation... for example, if I have a test #2 that add a new user to the
system, and I expect an error (password not strict enough, for example),
and this test fails, that is it adds the user to the system. Normally,
if I have a test that adds a user, I would delete the user afterward,
but for this case, since I didn't expect the user to be added, I don't
do the cleaning up. Then on my test #5, I check how many users in the
system, I would expect none, and the test will fail because the previous
test already added the user by error. (Sure, in this simple case, I can
check the result and if the user is successfully added, I can delete,
but I just want to give an example, other cases may not as so easy). So,
I don't see a benefit of create a new instance, the tests still get
affected.


> 2. Do the tests run quickly enough even if you "waste" the resources?

Well, right now it still runs quick enough... but I don't know if I
write more tests into the class it will be fast or not... I have to
parse an xml file to get all the parameters for the tests, and I rather
parse once for all the tests to keep in the system than to parse over
and over the file for each test case because each time a new instance is
created.

Thanks for your clarification, though,

Vietchau
